Posts.Content: KOT-Glad you found this forum. It has a lot of members with some really valuable experience. I recommend you look up the threads that will help you prepare for your surgery. They have a lot of good info. I had my RALP on December 29 and I was back to work after 3 weeks. Recovery is pretty painless except for the catheter which is a pain in the ass! But it will be out after about a week and it is downhill from there. Hang in there and Happy Easter!

Only used one pad/day from the beginning and could probably get along without one but I use it just in case of small leaks when lifting. I do however still get up 3 times/night. I am now 2 years post surgery. Don't think that will change. I think the bladder size was reduced or something during the surgery.

Posts.Content: RedBull, I am 7 months post-op and 2 months post radiation and have had no erections. It does get depressing and at times I feel like I am letting my wife down but I know she doesn't think that way. It is just hard to accept that life has changed for me forever. I used to have so much energy and since finishing the radiation treatments I can barely mow the yard anymore. I go back to see my urologist today and get my first PSA results post radiation. I will bring up these issues with him and see what I can do about it. Trying to stay positive and hope that in time I can return to a fairly normal life.

Posts.Title: Good bye Mr. Foley!!

Posts.Content: I concur with RobLee statements regarding ART. I was scheduled to have ART as soon as I could after RP because of my adverse pathology report (see signature). I didn't even question them because I was still kind of shell shocked from the whole cancer diagnosis. On one hand, I kind of wish I would have waited and watched my PSA levels first and maybe did more research on the pros & cons of ART. It wasn't cheap and I worry about the long term SE's. On the other hand, I think it was important to throw a one-two punch at my aggressive cancer. Anyway, I am playing the cards I was dealt. Now I just play the waiting game every six months and hope for the best.

Posts.Content: Ann I also had RALP followed by 38 rounds of radiation. I had some stomach pain for a few months after my treatments were finished, but they went away eventually. My stomach still makes a LOT of noise after I eat which can be embarrassing at work but no big deal really. Also my bowel movements are more frequent which I believe to be a result of the radiation. If he is having pain in his groin I would definitely go have it checked out. It might just be some lingering after effects from surgery and/or radiation.

Posts.Title: Incisional Hernia - anyone experienced?

Posts.Content: Ann I also had RALP followed by 38 rounds of radiation. I had some stomach pain for a few months after my treatments were finished, but they went away eventually. My stomach still makes a LOT of noise after I eat which can be embarrassing at work but no big deal really. Also my bowel movements are more frequent which I believe to be a result of the radiation. If he is having pain in his groin I would definitely go have it checked out. It might just be some lingering after effects from surgery and/or radiation.

Posts.Title: PSA result wait time

Posts.Content: I have to pretty much agree with Michigan. It has been overall a pretty lousy 16 months since my journey began. #1 had SRT 4 months after surgery due to aggressiveness of cancer (which has messed my insides up pretty good). #2 continence is pretty good but still sucks knowing you will probably have to wear a pad the rest of your life. #3 That soldier has been dead since the minute I had my surgery and with the radiation added on top of it I doubt he will ever return. Add to all of this the medical bills and depression that I have been experiencing lately and anxiety every time I get ready for another PSA check. Just never thought I would be dealing with this kind of stuff at the age of 52. I knew all of these risks were part of the deal, but it still sucks. Sorry for venting.

Posts.Title: Radiation starting soon, what is best way to protect other parts

Posts.Content: Hi Busby, I was 52 when I had my surgery 3 years ago. I pretty much agree with everyone else on here. I had very minimal pain from the surgery. Spent most of my time on the sofa but made sure to get up and walk around every so often. I only used Aleve for the pain. The prescription meds do cause constipation and you don't want that. I left the large bag on the whole time and only switched to the small leg bag when I went to my apt to have the catheter removed. I found the catheter to be the worst part of the whole ordeal also. I had a lot of pain at the tip where the catheter went in whenever I would move around. If I was sitting still it was fine. I did find that lubricating the tube at the tip helped. Also be sure to pull the tip back a little ways and clean it with a warm rag often. I was marking the days on my calendar to get the damn thing removed and it was a great day! It is a little scary when they are getting ready to pull it out but honestly it wont hurt. Good luck to you and keep us posted.

Posts.Title: My da Vinci date is January 9

Posts.Content: I had my prostate removed via davinci robotic 4 weeks ago. My doctor is now pushing for radiation therapy as soon as I heal. I have read a lot of pros and cons of this treatment. Any info you could give me would be very appreciated. Here are my results: Gleason 9 (4+5). EPI (+) (+) PNI SVI (+) Portion of prostate involved by tumor 95%. PT3b. Seminal vesicle invasion present. extraprostatic extension present. perineural invasion present, extensive. No regional lymph node metastasis. Is it worth it to try radiation or too late? I have heard radiation can cause many more problems. I am very confused. BTW I am 52 yrs old and otherwise very healthy. Thanks.
Posts.Title: Need advice on radiation therapy pros and cons

Posts.Content: Yes I had it after my prostate was removed. I thought everyone used it for radiation but I am finding out that many did not.

Posts.Title: Radiation starting soon, what is best way to protect other parts

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon Hello and welcome. One year after DaVinci surgery my PSA reached a point where I had 33 rounds of radiation. It has been almost three years since the radiation and my PSA is still undetectable. I experienced no side effects really, other than the inconvenience of having to maintain a full bladder for the procedure. Each treatment will about 12 minutes so not time consuming. If I were you I would get it done asap. Good luck Allen Thank you to all who posted. I do realize this is a serious situation. I am going to get the radiation in April after I heal from surgery. 4 weeks in my incontinence is almost gone and I am back to work and feeling good. FYI my PSA was not a factor in my diagnosis. I had been having a lot of problems with frequent urination, trouble starting stream, urgency, etc. When my doctor did a digital exam he found that my prostate was hard as a rock. He did an immediate biopsy and found entire prostate was cancerous.

Posts.Title: Need advice on radiation therapy pros and cons

Posts.Content: Hi Charlie's wife, I just wanted to chime in as another G9 survivor. I had my RALP in Dec 2015 and followed up with RT as soon as I recovered from surgery (see my signature). I wanted to make sure I had hit the cancer with all I could because mine was pretty aggressive. The radiation was really not a problem except for some fatigue in the last couple of weeks. Just letting you know that I am doing very well so far and feel I have pretty much gotten back to normal. I still use 1 pad a day and have some ED issues but overall I am in good health. Wishing you and your husband the best on your journey.

Posts.Title: OK, now I'm REALLY depressed

Posts.Content: Hi Tim, I was only in the hospital overnight. As soon as you can pass gas they let you go. Recovery from the surgery wasn't bad at all. I was home alone most of the time but had no problems. I binge watched 5 seasons of Game of Thrones and ate whatever I wanted. The catheter was uncomfortable at the tip of the penis but if you keep it lubricated it is bearable. I had no spasms or excruciating pain. I slept in bed just kept the big catheter bag below me on the floor. Some good advice I got is be careful around door knobs,etc. You don't want to catch that tube on anything and have it pull! My continence came back almost immediately after catheter was out (BTW that is scary when they get ready to pull it out but it really doesn't hurt). It was nice because after surgery I could pee like I was 18 again! Good luck on your surgery you will get through it just fine.

I am going to talk to my urologist at my next apt in February about trying the trimix injection. I hope that works because I don't think I want to go the surgical route.

Posts.Title: Update and ED Question

Posts.Content: Congrats on a successful surgery. Recovery should be pretty smooth. Just remember, no lifting anything heavy (even if you feel like you can) until doc OKs it. Keep catheter bag sterile and be careful of snagging the tube on doorknobs, etc (OUCH!). The catheter was the worst part for me, but it will be out in around 7 days. It seems scary when they are getting ready to pull it out but it doesn't hurt. Smooth sailing after that. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Surgery is done tpjames wife reporting

Posts.Content: Hi ANWANK-yes that catheter was the worst part of the recovery for me also. It was like an almost constant soreness at the tip of my penis, especially when walking and moving around. I could get to a comfortable spot while sitting down but once I got up it started hurting again. I also started to have a slight discharge where the tube went in that freaked me out. I called the uro office and they told me it was normal. Not much your fianc can do but keep it lubed, try not to move it too much and count down the days until removal. Also, when it's time to pull it out it can be pretty scary but it doesn't hurt at all. That will be a good day! Good luck.

Posts.Title: 6 days only for catheter removal

Posts.Content: Great news on the recovery progress. I had a pretty easy recovery too. I was also VERY nervous about them pulling the catheter out. It seems like it will be excruciating but in fact it was a piece of cake! My continence was good from the start. Just slight dribbling. I wear 1 pad a day and some days I even forget and never had a problem. ED has been a problem for me but I had the 1-2 punch of surgery followed by radiation so that was expected. I just want to stress that even though you may be feeling back to normal, DO NOT do anything strenuous for a while. I tried to move a dresser a couple weeks after surgery and immediately felt it inside my stomach. Good luck to you on the rest of your journey!

Posts.Title: Wife in full remission

Posts.Content: MM: Yes I forgot to update my signature. My last PSA on 2/4/19 was still 0.01. So far I have avoided the HT. Continence has been good (1 pad/day for small leaks). Haven't had any luck with erections since my davinci though. I miss my pre-diagnosis body. Hard to stay upbeat sometimes. I think I need to take the advice of some of the posters on here and get out and enjoy the weather/exercise more. I did recently buy a kayak and rigged it for fishing. I really enjoy that.

Posts.Title: Penile implant

Posts.Content: Hi Smasherie , I am near your fathers age (56) and was also diagnosed as a gleason 7 but upgraded to gleason 9 after surgery. I had 38 rounds of adjuvant radiation after I had healed from surgery and as you can see from my signature my PSA has been undetectable since then. I was pretty scared to hear gleason 9 at first but I am feeling pretty much back to normal and am starting to think they may have gotten it all. Hang in there and just make sure your father weighs all of his options. The worst part of this disease for most of us is the side effects from the surgery/radiation/HT, but you learn to deal with them. Just keep giving him your support.

Posts.Title: I have a question

Posts.Content: Hey Lantz, I did 40 rounds of radiation after my RP. It wasn't bad at all. Went to work everyday and stopped by for my 15 minute radiation treatment on the way home. I only got fatigued near the last week but it wasn't too bad. Just didn't have as much energy as usual but it wears off a few weeks after treatment. I haven't done HT so I can't say how that will affect you. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: Penile implant

Posts.Content: Fresh fruits and veggies give me extreme gas since radiation also. If I eat a salad with Italian dressing at work, everyone in my office will hear my stomach making loud noise for the next hour! I have also had more bowel movements than pre-radiation. Haven't really figured out what foods are worse for me but some times I feel like I am crapping battery acid. Probably the fruit but I just don't want to give up eating healthy.

Posts.Title: Mr. Foley, how I hate thee

Posts.Content: Hi Ireland, I had similar readings as your father. My PSA was fairly low (3.5)but my gleason score is 9. I actually had the RALP (surgery) followed by 40 rounds of radiation to hopefully knock out anything that might have escaped the prostate. Now I get to play the waiting game and check my PSA levels every few months. I'm pretty sure your doctors will suggest the same thing because of the high gleason score. Wishing you good luck.

Posts.Content: Hi Breezy' I just want to say I kind of know how you feel. My daughter is 19 and I found her crying in her room one day after we found out about my cancer diagnosis. I just had to let her know that I am doing everything I can to beat this. I'm 53 and I plan on being around for a long time. Your dad will be ok. They have come a long way with treatments for prostate cancer. Just hang in there and have faith.

If I had the low PSA and biopsy like you I would definitely wait and watch. You have a lot of time to make a choice. Enjoy being the man you are now because once you have the surgery or radiation life changes. I hope for the best for you.
